node.text:
The voiceover is what I had as my profile on Ok Cupid, which is how we met. Love—sustainable love—isn’t always easy for me. There were hurdles that I wasn’t always sure we’d make and challenges I couldn’t guarantee we’d withstand. And even today, after 3 years of being in “wedded bliss,” I know enough about life that promises and vows can be rewritten over time. So, while I can’t tell you what the future holds, I can tell you what today holds: my commitment to put as much work into our partnership as anything I’ve ever done in my life—more than my job, my marathons, my blog, my anything. Happy Anniversary, my love and darling and sweetheart. I am so grateful that God brought you into my life. 
📸: @kenny_kim

node.text: “When the cat’s away…” I used to love music. I once harbored the cliched hope of being a professional musician. But, adulting got in the way. Instead, I ended up marrying one of the greatest pianists alive. ☺️ Ironically, I almost never play anymore because I feel silly doing so in his presence. But, when I have the entire house to myself and the piano is just sitting there… also, sorry. I don’t know how to play anything but praise songs (I used to be a praise team leader at youth group), lol.

node.text:
Yesterday’s post sparked a very interesting conversation in the comments regarding food access and privilege. This is one of the best things about tKV Community—we can be civil and compassionate with disparate points of view. This is an excerpt from my podcast with @robbie_lockie and @plantbasednews where I provide my thoughts on the “barriers to entry” to a plant based diet. I used to be one of those persons who would passionately say “but vegan diets are so much cheaper! And will lower your medical bills to boot!” But I realized after talking with many ppl—vegans and non vegans alike—that this ignores the psychic cost of radically changing your life when life is doing so freaking much to get in the way. With a global pandemic as our collective backdrop, and millions who’ve lost their jobs and even loved ones, it simply isn’t kind much less enough to say “well you can get beans and rice at chipotle for $2.” We need to do better. We can do better. 

Link to full podcast:

https://podcasts.google.com/feed/aHR0cDovL2ZlZWRzLnNvdW5kY2xvdWQuY29tL3VzZXJzL3NvdW5kY2xvdWQ6dXNlcnM6MjgxOTkzNTg0L3NvdW5kcy5yc3M/episode/dGFnOnNvdW5kY2xvdWQsMjAxMDp0cmFja3MvMTA1OTcwMTk3Nw

node.text:
I recently had the opportunity to sit down with @robbie_lockie over at @plantbasednews for their podcast and it was the first time I was able to really talk, in depth, about my choice to adopt a plant based diet, and the reason I continue to stay committed to a vegan lifestyle. I know many of you who follow me are not vegan (perhaps “plant curious”?), but it is a side to me that plays an increasingly large role in my choices and thus my identity. I view the world’s troubles—racism, poverty, war—as problems that will be rendered moot if we don’t fix the existential crisis posed by climate change. Accordingly, the ailments that surfaced over the past few years in the United States have been imbued with greater urgency. Put simply, I worry that if we don’t get honest with climate change right now, we won’t have the luxury of time to treat the other illnesses of the world.
.
I am by no means a climate activist. I come to this as much a neophyte as many of you. I still probably do a lot of things that many veteran climate experts would view as horrifying. But, I am trying to do my part to make the world not just a better place, but a viable place for all of us.
.
Throughout the past 5+ years I’ve been vegan, many people (mostly other vegans) have tried to peg me as a “vegan for health,” “vegan for the animals,” or “vegan for the planet.” I find these buckets to be unhelpful, because I’m all three or none at all, depending on the context.  I’m just me—Joanne—a girl who loves animals, who cares about her body, and who wants to ensure that our children’s children’s children get to see the world in all its unscathed beauty.
.
Thank you to Robbie and the PBN team for giving me the chance to share this side to me.  You can find this episode of the Plant Based Podcast on Sound Cloud, iTunes, or anywhere else you listen to podcasts.

node.text:
My grandmother was such a hard woman. She wasn’t like the grandmothers we saw on tv—cuddly and sweet and smelling of cinnamon. Hahlmuhnee was severe, impatient, and carried with her the scent of gochugaru. Still, my brother and I loved her fiercely.  More than anyone in my life, she made me feel safe and protected throughout the wildling days of my childhood. At night, she’d coax me to sleep with tales of tigers and sisters and the moon, but she never told me about her past. What it was like growing up. How she met her husband, my grandfather. Why she could speak Japanese. How she coped with being a young widow when her husband passed away. What it was like being a single mother in Korea. I wish I had asked her those questions, because I think there was a part of her that wanted to share them.
.
Hahlmuhnee used to make us kimbap all the time. For every road trip, every picnic, even for my lunchbox. And nothing would get me angrier than seeing the neat piles of rolled kimbap packed into the cooler, wrapped in foil. Because it meant that, once again, we wouldn’t be getting Happy Meals. But she loved making kimbap. The methodical layering of the ingredients, the gentle pressure against the bamboo, all culminating in the perfect round mouthful of everything that makes Korean food Korean food. Hahlmuhnee never ever uttered the words “I love you”—in either Korean, Japanese, or English. She didn’t have to. And now, I could eat kimbap every single day without complaint.
.
I’ve partnered with @adobe to honor #OurDearElders, and today, I honor my grandmother. My brave, ferocious, loving grandmother. Who slipped out of North Korea through swamp water and cut through the mountains on foot, all while keeping my father safe. Tell me, how do you honor your elders? How have their stories shaped you? What are some of the foods you like to eat in remembrance of those who came before you? Share how you honor them with #OurDearElders so that we can all join in on this beautiful discussion. #adobepartner

node.text: May is mental health awareness month. And it’s easy to believe that if we say all the right things, fill our lives with all the right buzzwords, our struggles will dissolve like an aspirin in a cup of water. Unfortunately, illnesses of the mind are not as straightforward as an infection or a cold. They are circuitous, elusive, and deceptive. Truth becomes sort of like a dream—you think you hold it before it evaporates with the day to day. Seeking out and committing to consistent therapy as a young adult was a crucial part of growing into a life I could participate in with my eyes wide open. But so were the soulmates who jumped into the trenches with me and dragged me out when I’d lost the strength to do so myself.

node.text:
First time cooking red sauce from scratch? I got you! This recipe is so easy and versatile, it’s perfect for beginner cooks who really want to impress everyone who thinks you can’t cook. ☺️☺️ Make this sauce FROM SCRATCH from beginning to end and you will fall in love with cooking, tomatoes, and yourself!

https://thekoreanvegan.com/mouthwatering-braised-tomatoes/

node.text: This is the most frequent #AskAunty question I get and honestly, I tend to think of it in the platonic sense. I’m one of those persons who really has to remind herself that not everyone is going to like me. And that’s TOTALLY OK.

node.title: Advice from 고모: when they don’t like you back...

node.text:
Made a quick and dirty kimchi fried rice to to with my doenjang chigae! You can find the recipe for this on my blog too:

https://thekoreanvegan.com/ez-no-chop-kimchi-fried-rice/

If you want to know how I make my kimchi? Check out the link for my cookbook!

https://thekoreanvegan.com/the-korean-vegan-cookbook/

If you make this, make sure to tag me!!

node.text: My take on chicken adobo. Will be posting this to the blog this weekend. In the meantime, enjoy!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Korean Vegan, Esq. on August 01, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Can Joanne Lee Molinaro, the Korean Vegan, ever stop overachieving? Joanne Lee Molinaro started her blog, the Korean Vegan, in 2016. (Christina House Los Angeles Times) BY STEPH CHA AUG. 1, 2021 6 AM PT'.

node.text: Thank you to the @latimes and @latimesfood for this lovely, thoughtful and intimate piece about my journey as The Korean Vegan! The last 5 years have been a wild ride, and I cannot wait to take you all with me as the adventure continues!! Link to this article is in my bio!

node.text: What do you like to put in your oatmeal? I started doing this when my mom told me she added 김 (seaweed) to her oatmeal in the morning. 😋

node.text:
In high school, I knew a girl named Sarah.  She was tall, slender, sported sleek black hair and looked and smelled like she’d walked out of the pages of Vogue. When we talked, our conversations covered makeup, hairstyles, flared jeans, and boys.  She liked to laugh a lot, in that flirty, some might call annoying “look at me look at me” way. One day, while in the girls room, she casually mentioned that she often purged after eating lunch, like it was nothing. A lot of people didn’t like Sarah.  They thought she was shallow, superficial, or stupid.  And maybe she was all of those things, but any time someone looked down on her, I would think of that moment in the bathroom, because, in my mind, anyone who feels pain bears some depth.
.
It’s very easy to look at people and judge their pain. “Oh, grow a pair” or “get over yourself” or “toughen up already!” Many people in my generation lament what they view as a “weakening” taking place across the younger generations. The kind of toughness the older generations might revere, however, comes at a steep cost—a growing lack of empathy. When someone is undergoing deep psychological pain over a trauma that might appear silly or frivolous to you, what does it cost you to be kind, generous, and compassionate in lieu of contemptuous and superior? Nothing.  And, in fact, an open mind can often facilitate the kind of wisdom that girds the type of strength that doesn’t just move mountains, but also moves hearts.
.
I say all these things because this post is me sharing something that I don’t particularly like about myself. And many people have already criticized me for being “shallow” or “privileged” or “superficial” for caring so much about my appearance.  You all know I share these things because I hate it when people suffer alone. It is wasteful, counterproductive, and unnecessary.  But for those of you who would look at me or anyone else who suffers from body dysmorphia or something akin to it—please think twice before thinking, “god, they’re so shallow.” Matters of the human heart are never shallow.

node.text:
I started The Korean Vegan in 2016, never thinking that a food blog could ever be deemed “creative,” certainly not artistic. After all, I was just veganizing my favorite Korean foods. Where’s the creativity in that? Sure, I was taking photos and learning a lot about how to make them look a certain way, but I wasn’t any good. I didn’t have a degree in photography. I barely knew what most of the buttons on my camera even did. Even when I started adding captions to my instagram posts—stories about my family—these were little more than journal entries.  Factual descriptions of things that had already happened—hardly the kind of elevated creativity that I thought could be categorized as prose or real “writing.”
.
Fast forward to last summer, when I posted my first real TikTok. I hardly knew what the heck I was doing. I looked down in my comments and I was identified as a “Creator.” Other TikTok users were calling me a “Creator”! And I thought it was so strange. After convincing myself that I was anything but creative, the fact that so many people were calling me that word was surreal. Over the next year, I did everything I could to live up to that title—on TikTok and here on Instagram, the community that has been with me since Day 1.  The fact that you all believed in me when I didn’t is unspeakably moving to me.
.
As many of you know, my book comes out this October. Just a few days ago, I got to hold it in my hands. I cannot wait for all of you to see it, to hold it the way I got to, to feel the pages of my heart fluttering between your fingers as you breathe in my words, as you eat my food, as you live through my stories.  As the release date inches closer, it’s getting real-real, in a way that confounds description, other than to say, Thank you.  Thank you thank you thank you, for seeing something in me I thought I’d deleted.
.
And, yes, you can pre-order a copy today—link in bio or here: https://thekoreanvegan.com/the-korean-vegan-cookbook/. 💕❤️

node.text:
I was very hesitant to post this because I think we need to be very careful about advising anyone—particularly a young person—that the right answer is to cut off their parents.  But, I’ve been getting so many requests for advice on this topic and it almost always comes from an individual struggling with their sexuality. I watched a video yesterday of a man in his 60s who said that the most heartbreaking experience of his life was when his parents told him that if didn’t stop being gay, he would stop being their son.  He was 17 years old and he hasn’t seen his parents since.
.
That level of betrayal from the two people who are supposed to love you no matter what is not the kind of wound that will “heal with time.” Some wounds won’t ever heal. Rather than promoting some BS notion that “time heals all wounds,” it’s better to equip people with the tools necessary to live with scars. For me, it’s always very irritating when I feel like something is wrong with me for not healing, for not “getting over” something at some predetermined pace of “reasonability.” There is no “reasonable” when dealing with hurts like this—the man whose video I watched clearly hasn’t healed after all these years and who can blame him?
.
The idea that parents can do no wrong, that they have some irretrievable sacrosanct license to be in their children’s lives no matter what they do is dangerous.  The fact is, parents can cause more psychic damage than any other human in a young person’s life.  I wish it weren’t so, I wish there weren’t as many young people out there who are hurting because of their parents, but after engaging with my community this past year, it has become evident to me that I am incredibly lucky to have the parents I do—because many people do not.
.
To anyone who might be grappling with toxic family members, you have my heart. I wish you courage and power, as you write your story—not theirs.

node.text:
The voiceover is what I had as my profile on Ok Cupid, which is how we met. Love—sustainable love—isn’t always easy for me. There were hurdles that I wasn’t always sure we’d make and challenges I couldn’t guarantee we’d withstand. And even today, after 3 years of being in “wedded bliss,” I know enough about life that promises and vows can be rewritten over time. So, while I can’t tell you what the future holds, I can tell you what today holds: my commitment to put as much work into our partnership as anything I’ve ever done in my life—more than my job, my marathons, my blog, my anything. Happy Anniversary, my love and darling and sweetheart. I am so grateful that God brought you into my life. 
📸: @kenny_kim

node.text:
My mother was about as “in your face” as she could be in our home and my father has been politically active since he was a teenager. I cannot begin to describe how grateful I am for their indirect tutelage, the values they instilled in me, and the tools they gave me to voice my opposition to the things I view as wrong. My parents are still immigrants, though. And often times, the language and cultural barriers, as well as the insecurity that inheres to assimilation, disguise micro-aggression so well, it becomes susceptible to internalization. This breaks my heart. And makes me so angry. Because my parents don’t deserve that.
.
Some ppl will watch this and say, what’s the big deal? Some ppl don’t want their kimchi prepared on the floor. But that misses the point. That precise attitude—one that my mother predicted—is what will eradicate traditional practices from cultural cuisine. Why do we make kimchi on the floor? Because it’s meant to be a communal activity. Kimchi making day is a full day affair, with women from not just your entire family but the entire village gathering together to salt and sauce the cabbage. You need to get all up in there, sometimes elbow deep, and the most efficient way to do that with so many ppl is to put it on a level surface that is within arms reach of several, with sufficient leverage to do so for long periods of time (hence, the “kimchi squat”). I am happy to explain this to the curious, but saddened to explain it to the arrogant and condescending, those who think that their way—the way of the dominant culture—is the ONLY right way.
.
I didn’t post this to my Insta (it’s been on my TikTok for awhile), because it’s been a bit tiring dealing with the amount of times I’ve been told “you’re making a bit deal out of nothing,” “ewwww I wouldn’t want to eat off your floor [news flash there’s a freaking bowl],” or, my personal favorite “you’re racist.” But gaslighting comes with the territory and I need to learn how to cope with it.
.
The recipe link for this amazing vegan pop “chicken” is in my bio. Or here: https://thekoreanvegan.com/ricepop-ricepaper-tofu/
Enjoy. It’s a winner for sure.

node.text: For everyone who needs to hear it: you have permission to eat what you want, take the time that you need, and sleep as much as your body requires. Sometimes we like to use our “obligations” as pretexts for our own unwillingness to bend, our need for control. Because that is the truth of it: our obsession with discipline and “productivity” is oftentimes nothing more than a twisted manifestation of our anxiety, our desperation for some semblance of control. And of course that is understandable given what we’ve all been put through this past year and a half. But tightening the screws is the exact opposite of what our bodies need right now. We need rest. A lot of it. So, I’ll say it again: give yourself permission to rest. Also, link to the recipe of this Ricepaper Stuffed Tteokbokki in bio. ❤️
